title: How to Print on Cardstock: Step-by-Step Guide & Helpful Tips

steps.title: Load the cardstock into your printer.
steps.content: Load the cardstock into your printer. If you're printing on a smaller piece of cardstock, adjust the paper width guides in the paper tray to fit the cardstock (if your printer has them).

steps.title: Open the print dialog.
steps.content: Open the print dialog. How you do this depends on your operating system and program, but you can usually access it by clicking the File option at the top of the screen and choosing Print . In many programs, the shortcut Ctrl + P (Windows) or ⌘ Cmd + P (Mac) will also open the print dialog. Before continuing, make sure your document or project is ready to be printed and that you've changed the document size to match the size of cardstock that you have. How you do this varies depending on the program and/or operating system you're using, but the option is usually found in the File or Edit menu under Page Setup (or something similar). If the program opens its own print window and you don't see the options listed in this guide, look for an option to open the system print dialog. You may have to look under Other options (or something similar) to find this.

steps.title: Open your printer's properties.
steps.content: Open your printer's properties. On PC, click the Properties button in the print dialog window. On Mac, click Page Setup .

steps.title: Set your document's paper type.
steps.content: Set your document's paper type. Look for an option that says Paper Type or Media Type . In the dropdown, look for a paper option that says "cardstock," "thick," or "heavy." If you don't see any of these options, you could also try selecting an option for photo paper, as it's thicker than regular printer paper. Each printer has different paper type options. Even if the printer doesn't have a cardstock, choosing any type of thicker paper will more than likely work. However, you may have to try a few different options until the printer prints your document correctly. If your printer doesn't have options other than plain paper, you still might be able to print on thinner cardstock—but be aware that your printer might jam .

steps.title: Set your document's orientation.
steps.content: Set your document's orientation. To do this, look for the Orientation section in the printer's properties. Then, change the setting to portrait or landscape. The option may be a dropdown or a button you can click. By default, your printer will print in the portrait orientation. If your document is set to landscape orientation, you must change your printer's orientation to landscape, or it won't print properly.

steps.title: Set your document's size.
steps.content: Set your document's size. To do this, look for an option that says Paper Size , Page Size , or something similar. You can either choose a predefined paper size from the dropdown, or you can enter your paper size by selecting Custom or similar (Windows) or Manage Custom Sizes on Mac. If you are printing on letter size or A4 paper (around 8.5" x 11"), you shouldn't have to change the document's size in the print dialog since letter/A4 is the default size for most printer paper.

steps.title: Click OK to exit the Properties/Page Setup window.
steps.content: Click OK to exit the Properties/Page Setup window. This will return you to the main print dialog window.

steps.title: Ensure the rest of the information is correct.
steps.content: Ensure the rest of the information is correct. Make sure you've chosen the correct tray (if your printer has more than one), whether to print in black and white or color, and the number of copies to print. If this is your first time printing a project, you may want to print only one copy at a time to test it until you know that your printer settings are set up correctly.

steps.title: Click Print to print your document.
steps.content: Click Print to print your document. After your document prints, you may need to tweak your settings if the print doesn't turn out how you expected. If not, continue and print all of the copies you need if you haven't already.

steps.title: Many—but not all—modern printers can print on cardstock.
steps.content: Many—but not all—modern printers can print on cardstock. This includes both regular inkjet and laser printers. To check if your printer can print on cardstock, look for the printer's technical or paper specifications in the manual or online. If the specs only list a paper weight and not a paper type, check if the accepted range includes between 65lb and 110lb (the weight range for cardstock paper). [1] X Research source

steps.title: Look for a printer that can print on cardstock.
steps.content: Look for a printer that can print on cardstock. If you're looking to buy a new printer, look for one that says it can print on cardstock. Below is a (non-exhaustive) list of some popular printers that print on cardstock: Canon PIXMA series* Canon PIXMA Pro series* Epson EcoTank Series* Epson XP 15000 HP ENVY 6055e HP DeskJet 2842e HP OfficeJet 3830 * Some printers in this series may not print on cardstock

steps.title: Go to a print shop.
steps.content: Go to a print shop. If you can't print on cardstock at home, the best option is to go to a print shop. Print shops have high-quality, professional printers that can print on a wide variety of materials in custom sizes. However, print shops can get a bit pricey depending on the shop and what you are printing. If you go the print shop route, shop around to find the best prices.

steps.title: Ask a friend.
steps.content: Ask a friend. If you have a friend with a printer that can print on cardstock, you could ask them to use their printer. However, if you need to print a lot of copies, you may want to go to a print shop instead. If your friend is okay with you printing a big print job, consider offering to reimburse them for the ink used to finish printing everything.

steps.title: Print on regular paper and glue it to a thicker backing.
steps.content: Print on regular paper and glue it to a thicker backing. If nothing else works, you can print your document or project on normal printer paper, and then glue it to a thick piece of cardstock or even some cardboard. This option is not recommended for something professional like an invitation or a business card, but it can work in a pinch for a school project or a craft.
